title: Should universities weigh in on Trump's statements?

David Jesse , Detroit Free Press Published 6:43 p.m. ET Feb. 3, 2017 | Updated 4 minutes ago Buy Photo Since President Donald Trump took office, people across the country and on university campuses have protested. Over 3,000 people made up of women, men of different races and religions marched on the campus of Wayne State University in Detroit, Michigan on Saturday, January 21, 2017. It was one of many marches going on to coincide with the big women's march being held in Washington D.C. to send a message to the new president Donald Trump. It was one of many marches going on to coincide with the big women's march being held in Washington D.C. to send a message to the new president Donald Trump. The marchers carried a variety of signs ranging for equal treatment and equal pay to hands off women's rights. (Photo: Eric Seals, Detroit Free Press) Buy Photo 
It’s the uncertainty that’s stressing out Donna Fard. 
Will President Donald Trump’s temporary ban on visas for people from her home country of Iran be lifted in time for her brother to make a planned visit this summer, or her sister to come soon so they can grieve their father’s January death together? Will she be able to get a visa when she’s done with her studies at Michigan Technological University? 
“I don’t know if it’s temporary or not,” said Fard, a doctoral student who expects to graduate ths year. “If I knew it was going to be in place permanently I could look for another country to go to. I picked (coming here) with my brain, not with my heart, because I had to leave my family. Was it worth it?”
